title: Will the 2016 industry-wide average cost of Li-on batteries used in battery-powered electric vehicles be less than $300 per kWh?
preds: (no change but) Not long before Mack reads the entrails.
Because of the "industry-wide average" part of the question.

Tesla claims to pay $190. In the last few years, they have been 25-60% below the average market-price as calculated by the Nature-article (link in question description), although the numbers fluctuate a lot. The 'bandwidth' of the estimates is also quite large.  Lots of uncertainty, and I've been above consensus most of the time.

Not sure how representative developments by Tesla Motors are but willing to take the overall quantitative trend seriously Does anyone know whether the average will be weighted by capacity produced in MWh? My interpretation of one of the graphs in the paper is that the prices bottom at the level of Tesla (around 300 $). This view is expressed in the cited Nature article. Taking into account the raw material price increase I still doubt the continued steep decline in costs. 
Over all 5 % is really to pessimistic up to 10 %.
Lithium prices go up as demand rises. No new battery technology will see mass production soon. So the prices have no reason to drop. No way the will drop even sharper than the cited 14 % per year.

As of 2014, average cost of Li-on batteries industry wide was $410 per kWh, falling at a rate of about 14% per year. Following this trend results in an estimate of $303 per kWh by 2016. Batteries, unlike computer technology, are not subject to Moore's Law.  There is a limit, chemically, to how much power you can get from a battery of a given size.  Manufacturing techniques can lower cost of the things, so it's possible, but I don't think the cost will automatically drop.

This is a silly forecast.  The ending dollar amount doesn't matter, because it is known that the cost will continue to decline as the technology,  production processes and sales mature.  Limiting the cost to Lithium Ion is also silly, this is a field where there is a lot of interest, new technologies disrupting the market nearly every month and by the time the prediction can come true, the next/best technology will be developed and restarting the price/performance/time cycle.  The better question would be what must be the market penetration of electric vehicles to provide the critical mass demand to meet this dollar target--that should be predictable with pretty high certainty.
Up 3% to stay slightly more above the consensus.

Please see link below for the background on this post
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/258792 After my query on the resolution methodology to GJO and their forwarding of the same to Mack Institute, Mack Institute has replied to GJO as follows, "The best-fit trend line will be based on the 2007-2016 data that will include the cost-estimates in the Nature Climate Change article (Nykvist and Nilsson, 2015), and updated with the recent cost-estimates that we will obtain for 2014, 2015 and 2016." Based on my position explained in the link above, I am dropping my forecast to 72% from 80%.
It seems that projecting the trend will take us close. So I will say that it will probably happen.

There are two ways (only?) in which this question can be resolved. One is to include the old data from 2007-14 while doing the analysis, and the other way is to base it only on the data sourced from 2014-16 period.  If it is the latter approach, probability is very high that industry-wide average cost in 2016 will be below $300. I would put it at >85%. Why? Because the starting point for the projection (i.e., average cost in 2014 done on a fresh slate) is likely to be about $50 below the $410 level given by the old study. This is of course assuming that the new data from 2014 takes the same shape as the old data on 2014. If they decided to carry over the old data on 2014 into the new study as well, the $50 drop becomes a near certainty. If we apply a very conservative 10% decline (as opposed to the empirically observed 14%) on that lower starting base in 2014, the cost drops below $300.  However, if it is the former approach, estimating the probability is much harder. Extrapolating 14% decline on $410 takes us down to about $300, but not below it.   We would have to resort to a guess that since market leaders like Tesla and Nissan are more in the news these later years, their cost base will have more of a say in the data collected, and because of that the average cost is more likely to end up below $300. Because of the uncertainties involved, I would be uncomfortable giving more than about 70%-75% probability, in this resolution approach. I have written to GJO for clarity on which resolution is going to be used. Till I have that clarity, I am taking the mid-point of the probabilities suggested by the two approaches (72.5% & 90%), and giving a probability of 80%.
-----------------------------------
As an aside, the advantage of using a multiple year cost curve for resolving this question is that there is less uncertainty in the forecasting. A single year average can be thrown off by one or two outlier data points (what I was afraid of in my first post on this question - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/252972), but when we project from multiple years data, the calculation is likely to be more reliable and on expected lines.
-----------------------------------
Update: Please check out discussion on the methodology triggered by @dowser post for the background on this post.

Resolving this question through the paper's methodology may boil down to whether there are sufficient cost references from parts of the industry that are not the BEV leaders. If you look at the chart, it is clear that the last year studied (2014) has just one such reference compared to three that are from the BEV leaders. This makes sense because BEV leaders are now more in the news and are much more closely studied compared to rest of the industry.  What I am saying is that this question is more about forecasting the methodology, it is not about forecasting the supposed true cost of Li-ion batteries in the BEV industry by extrapolating from the best-fit curve. As such I am inclined to give it at least a 60% probability, given the likely preponderance of reports/papers/news on the BEV leaders in 2016.

Supply-demand is increasing as the performance of the battery powered cars now meets industry norms.  Supply growth will drive economies of scale in both R&D and production levels.  There is also an accelerator embedded here as lower costs will translate to lower car costs, and thus allow these cars to be in the purchase price range of larger numbers of buyers.
The cost trend certainly seems to indicate that the $300 barrier, if it's not already broken, will be broken by year-end.

GM announced in October 2015 that their cost per KwH is already at $145. It is however noted that the industry average cost is still around $350. But new models being developed by industry leaders, such as Tesla and GM will drive down the average cost faster.

For the leading manufacturers, the costs seem to be already in $300 range per kWh in 2014 as per Mach article as well as per the below article:
http://arstechnica.com/science/2015/07/electric-vehicle-batteries-are-getting-cheaper-much-faster-than-we-expected/ But, industry costs were $400 in 2014 - so industry leaders were 25% better on cost. Latest reports note that the cost is below $200 for both Tesla and GM:
Tesla: http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2016/04/26/teslas-battery-pack-costs-are-cheaper-than-you-thi.aspx
Ford: http://www.hybridcars.com/gm-ev-battery-cells-down-to-145kwh-and-still-falling/
Both: http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1103667_electric-car-battery-costs-tesla-190-per-kwh-for-pack-gm-145-for-cells So, let me assume $200 as the cost for the big guys. For them, the cost is now 2/3rd (~33%) of that in 2014.  Assume that for the industry, costs were down only 25%. This leads to my forecast that is right at $300. Now, that's tough. I'm starting with a 50-50 as my base case. Let me start adjusting.  If the industry matches Tesla-GM degree of cost reduction, then the industry cost is likely to be below $300. How likely? An important thing to note is that there is significant over-capacity in the automobile Li-ion battery industry as seen in slide 13 of below PDF:
http://evobsession.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/CEMAC-Automotve-Lithium-ion-Battery-LIB-Supply-Chain-and-U.S.-Competitiveness-Considerations-June-2015.pdf This could lead to battery manufacturers willing to cut prices, especially as costs in 2014 were ~$250. So, I'm going to take out half of the probability from 'No', and giving it to 'Yes'. 75% Yes is my starting forecast. Further reading required.

It seems to me that the technology required to lower the cost of battery packs to below $300 per kilowatt hour is based mostly the economics of scale for production. While there are still advances in battery technology research occurring that can lower the cost of production and increase the energy density of the batteries, much of the cost right now comes down to whether the infrastructure is already in place to produce the batteries themselves. http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/How-Soon-Can-Tesla-Get-Battery-Cell-Cost-Below-100-per-Kilowatt-Hour http://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/sustainability-and-resource-productivity/our-insights/battery-technology-charges-ahead While Tesla has been getting much of the press lately for the planned construction of gigawatt factories, in fact there are several automotive battery pack companies in play. The largest appears to LG Chem, which in fact has recently formed a new alliance with Tesla and will continue to provide batteries for Tesla vehicles. (Previously Tesla was using Panasonic battery packs.) LG Chem has several battery factories already built, including facilities in Holland, Michigan; Wanxiang, China; and Ochang, Korea. Back in October, LG Chem also announced that it would build a new factory for the European market (supporting its electric vehicle alliance with Renault). This factory will probably take at least two years to come online, judging by the timeline on the Wanxiang factory. http://www.forbes.com/sites/samabuelsamid/2015/10/28/lg-chem-may-be-on-the-verge-of-dominating-ev-battery-industry/#78484927144d http://insideevs.com/lg-chem-build-battery-plant-europe/ http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/LG-Chems-Energy-Storage-Business-Had-a-Good-Year http://www.autonews.com/article/20151214/OEM06/312149992/lg-chem-quietly-surges-in-battery-race While LG Chem is the largest producer, there are still other players in the game including Tesla's former partner Panasonic, NEC Corp, and A123 Systems. What this suggests to me is that there is already a great deal of manufacturing capacity in the game. Assuming that demand for Li-on battery packs does not rise greatly over the next year due to demands  in the vehicle and bulk energy storage markets, I think there is a better than even chance we will see the cost of battery packs drop below $300 per kwh by the end of 2016.

Since the 14% a year is an average, and the cost reduction is logrithmic, can't really see projecting the same rate for 2015 and 2016.  The decline should be less than 14%.  Leaving room for the +/-6%, however, it looks like the official estimate is on the trend line, which may negate the +/- factor. "Hard to read" chart lists the black line as a log fit on all data, which would include the historical data.  Looks like there is a declining cost reduction percentage over time, as should be.
Base line case: $410 (2014 figure) x 14% decrease leaves $352.6 in 2015 and similarly, $303.24 in 2016.  Even assuming the 14 % decline the kWh still comes in a little high.

From the paper: "Hence, we believe that the 8% annual cost decline for market-leading actors is more likely to represent the probable future cost improvement for Li-ion battery packs in BEV, whereas the 14% decline for the industry as a whole to some degree represents a correction of earlier, overestimated costs." In other words, the 14% is unlikely to continue because of the prior errors in estimation. At 8% annual reduction, the cost in 2016 is expected to be $347/kWh, and using the paper's stated MOE was +/- 8% (which per year means up to a 26% decline), we can still be over 95% confident that it will NOT fall below $300. Now, the paper did claim that the 8% figure is only more LIKELY to represent future cost reductions, and the paper also states the following: "It can be expected that the cost gap between market leaders and the industry as a whole will narrow over the coming years. In such a scenario... there is a convergence of estimates of battery cost for the whole industry and costs for market-leading car manufacturers in 2017–2018 at around US$230 per kWh." Remember these are leading car manufacturers, not the industry as a whole, but I still want to hedge my bets in that the actual drop will be somewhere between 8% and 14% annually, favoring 8%. All said, I'll go with a 10% chance that it falls below $300/kWh in 2016, meaning I think the consensus is way too high. Barring crazy advances in Li-ion technology, the 14% reduction continuing in 2015 and 2016 is unrealistic. I'm not going down to 5% Yes due to uncertainty in the original estimate of annual cost decreases.
It might make TO $300 by the end of 2016, but  the year's average likely higher.
Supply will come in from everywhere and prices will drop
If GM's low cost is a true low cost, other producers should quickly follow.

Given that the question is about "used" rather than purchased it is hard to see how the average could fall so quickly (given the accumulating installed base of vehicles) ..The Mack institute are looking at cost which I believe is a slightly different question.
This depends on some breakthroughs that could happen, but that are hard to foresee.

Up 10% to be closer to consensus. Wondering what "industry-wide" really includes? Would major companies (GM, Tesla, etc.) not want to show significant progress? Ditto for any "startup" competitors that need to scale and get funding.
Current prices would have to fall some way below $300/KWh to give an average 2016 below $300

Wasn't planning on forecasting this one but this article caught my attention:
http://www.computerworld.com/article/3060005/mobile-wireless/scientists-can-now-make-lithium-ion-batteries-last-a-lifetime.html
"She discovered that just by using this gel, she could cycle it hundreds of thousands of times without losing any capacity." "That was crazy," he added, "because these things typically die in dramatic fashion after 5,000 or 6,000 or 7,000 cycles at most." longer living=less demand for replacement=cheaper. Plus what others have already said.
China will use this market to bolster manufacturing as natural resources continue their slump.

Initial forecast. I too expect to regret joining. Does anyone know if the six main academic articles were using very similar data? If so, does that suggest that peer-review gets better projections or are they reinforcing a theme?  Another thought which leads me to lean toward @Raahul_Kumar forecast: If one studies EV/batteries, would one choose to go into that area of study because you think there are problems or because it might save the planet? Yes, I'm fairly certain which I'd bet on. Consequently, while not suggesting that analyses would be skewed, I do wonder about the data set being hopeful/positive.

Li-ion battery manufacture is tricky and bad batteries pose a fire risk.  No one wants that.   Also, Tesla's costs are the lowest and perhaps are decreasing at a slower rate than the other #'s (from squinting at the Nature graph...suppose I should try to access the full article).  Perhaps they'll plunge when the Gigafactory opens but that is expected in 2017, I think.   On the other hand, this appears to be average of reports of estimated cost, as opposed to average cost per battery.  That's a bit open to manipulation/noise, sort of dependent on what gets published, what point authors want to make, and what underlying data they can access.  A bit messy & unpleasant - I'd prefer some real numbers here and probably will regret forecasting.
Battery costs are always harder to lower than people think.  So just to start I'm going slightly no.

The cost to manufacture Li-on batteries will decrease, but the cost of electricity is rising in many areas.  The cost in one state may make this possible but in the Midwest or Hawaii, I don't see how this happens over the long term.

GM Says Li-ion Battery Cells Down To $145/kWh and Still Falling In a somewhat unusual move for an automaker, GM divulged this week it is far along the curve toward li-ion batteries cheap enough to sell its reasonably priced Bolt at a profit.Entering 2016 GM said its cells cost $145 per kilowatt-hour, and by late 2021, they could be at the $100 mark.  http://www.hybridcars.com/gm-ev-battery-cells-down-to-145kwh-and-still-falling/ Mass production lithium ion batteries are also coming online, so I do expect lithium ion prices to fall. 
http://cleantechnica.com/2015/10/31/samsung-opens-lithium-ion-battery-factory-in-china/
Data spread is huge, staying low without 2015 data

From a brief glance at the Mack chart, it looks like recent estimates have been less noisy than past estimates (only one number seems to have been available in 2007). As noise has dropped, so too has the real rate of cost decline. I'm going to skew low on this, even though some estimates already seem to be below $300/kWh, because I don't think that Mack's estimation procedure will change much.
